metadata.title: The Devil’s Music. Is Pitchfork Really The Internet’s… | by Callum Ballard | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: So reads the Pitchfork review of Music (as imagined by The Onion), which gives the “mode of creative expression consisting of sound and silence expressed through time” an altogether mediocre 6.8 out…

all_paragraphs: “Coming in at an exhausting 7,000 years long, Music is weighed down by a few too many mid-tempo tunes, most notably ‘Liebesträume №3 In A-Flat’ by Franz Liszt and ‘Closing Time’ by ’90s alt-rock group Semisonic… In the end, though Music can be brilliant at times, the whole medium comes off as derivative of Pavement…”

So reads the Pitchfork review of Music (as imagined by The Onion), which gives the “mode of creative expression consisting of sound and silence expressed through time” an altogether mediocre 6.8 out of 10 rating.

Pitchfork was launched in the mid ’00s, specialising in the reportage of independent and underground music in the American Midwest. From humble beginnings, it developed significant cultural capital. It now boasts nearly quarter of a million daily readers, and had no small hand in the early success of many bands that became household names (Arcade Fire’s debut LP, ‘Funeral’, briefly went out of print following the Pitchfork’s glowing review).

However, as The Onion’s spoof suggests, such unreserved praise is considered uncharacteristic. What the self-declared ‘Most Trusted Voice In Music’ giveth with one hand, it can certainly taketh with the other (many of my own favourite bands have taken a savaging over the years).

Pitchfork is often accused of being deliberately provocative and contrarian with its reviews in order to attract attention. Accusations of pretension (motivated by the site’s often verbose, tangential style) are further driven by Pitchfork’s decimal rating system, which means that it scores albums on a 0–100 scale, as opposed to the simple 5 star grading deployed by most traditional critics. It can often feel like this is the case solely to put down your favourite albums to an even greater level of precision.
Of course, to find out whether or not any of these accusations are justified, it makes sense to look at the data.
The datasets we will use for this analysis were generated by scraping the review-aggregation website, Metacritic (this process was covered in a previous blog).
Having done this, we have the following information about some 202,000 album reviews:

The ‘Metascore’ is a weighted average of an album’s different critic reviews. Though the exact methodology that Metacritic uses to create the Metascore is not konwn, Metacritic suggests that extra weight is given “based on [a publication’s] quality and overall stature”. It then normalises these scores (akin to “grading on a curve” in college) to prevent scores from clumping together. At any rate, the Metascore is the best measure we have for the ‘true’ quality of any given album.

Pitchfork has been one of the most prolific music publications of the last twenty years. Only two others have more reviews in the dataset, and since 2018, Pitchfork has published more reviews on a monthly basis than anyone else, aside from AllMusic.

There is a very crude way to measure a publication’s harshness — take an average of each publication’s review scores, and rank them. Doing this, we see that there are many harsher critics than Pitchfork, which just scrapes into the top (or bottom?) thirty publications.

Of course, this analysis is flawed. We’ve already seen that the publications have reviewed different numbers of albums — maybe it’s the case that Pitchfork has simply reviewed more good albums, given the breadth of its catalogue. We thus need to introduce a more robust measure of harshness.

We’ve already suggested that the Metascore is probably the best measure we have of an album’s true quality. Thus, we can identify a harsh review by comparing the Metascore with the individual review score.

Let’s isolate Pitchfork’s reviews. We can plot each review’s Pitchfork score against the corresponding Metascore. Albums that Pitchfork have reviewed ‘harshly’ therefore fall below the purple ‘x=y’ line. We can see a lot of points fall below that line — more than two thirds, in fact.

We can boil this ‘harshness’ concept down into a single KPI — a review’s ‘Difference to Metascore’. This is easily calculated as the difference between the two numbers. In the chart above, it would be given as the vertical distance between the point and the purple line.
So for Pitchfork’s review of the latest Foals album, the Difference to Metascore would be 60 minus 78, i.e. -18 (seemingly quite harsh!)

Therefore, the more negative ‘Difference to Metascores’ a publication has, the more harsh we can judge it to be. If we plot a histogram of Pitchfork’s score differences, we see that the majority of them are negative (which we knew from the above scatter plot).
On average, Pitchfork scores almost a whole half-star lower than we would expect, given the Metascores of the albums that it has reviewed.
If you’re wondering which albums are to be found in that long tail on the left, then we can only hope that you’re not a fan of Northern State…
One of the advantages of the ‘Difference to Metacritic’ KPI is that we can compare fairly across publications.

If we plot the mean score difference to Metascore for each publication, we actually see that Pitchfork doesn’t look especially remarkable — especially relative to other publications with a similar number of published reviews.

Many of the publications at the extremities of harshness and generosity (i.e. on the far left and far right of the above scatter) are much smaller concerns. The three harshest (Drawer B, Select, and Vulture) only published 318 reviews between them. The most generous are often ‘record of the week’ style columns, from which we would expect high scores.

If we isolate the top thirty publications (each with over 2,000 reviews in the dataset) we see that only a sixth of them review more generously than Metascores suggest they ought to — the only especially generous critic amongst them is Entertainment Weekly (make of that what you will). At any rate, by this measure, Pitchfork’s review scores don’t look particularly notable.

However, something interesting emerges if we go beyond the average score differences for each publication, and instead look at distribution of these differences. A histogram works if we’re doing this for one publication (as we did for Pitchfork a few paragraphs ago), however to compare multiple distributions side by side, we can use Seaborn’s violinplot function. Below, we plot the distributions for the ten most prolific publications in the dataset.
If we compare the score difference distributions for the these publications, there is something that stands out for Pitchfork — the distribution’s kurtosis.

Kurtosis is a measure of a distribution’s ‘tailedness’, and tells us how extreme its outliers are. The formula for kurtosis is constructed such that any datapoint within one standard deviation of the distribution’s mean contributes very little. Thus, a distribution that simultaneously has a low standard deviation and long tails is likely to have a high kurtosis.

Indeed, looking at Pitchfork’s ‘violin’ in the above plot, we see that it’s bunched quite tightly around the mean (resulting in a wide violin with steep slopes either side of the peak). It also has a very long negative tail.

Only Under The Radar has a more negative score difference within its distribution (they awarded a big fat zero to ‘Burned Mind’ by Wolf Eyes, to which, ever-obtuse, Pitchfork gave a highly commendable 8.0), however their score differences are much more loosely bunched.
If we plot all the publications on a scatter, we see that Pitchfork has one of the highest kurtosis scores of all critic in the dataset — certainly the highest of any big title.

Based on what we have seen, it doesn’t seem so. Of the main publications in the dataset, this award probably goes to Under The Radar, who, across nearly 5,000 reviews, under-scores by almost 7 percentage points on average.

What we can say about Pitchfork, however, is that it’s actually quite consistent. It tends to under-score albums, but not by an egregious amount relative to other publications of a similar size. In fact, of the top thirty publications, Pitchfork has the highest share of review scores within ‘half a star’ of the Metascore. In other words, it seems to be pretty good at judging an album’s ‘true quality’.

However, Pitchfork’s review scores contain a small number of significant outliers (the likes of ‘Dying In Stereo’, ‘nyc ghosts & flowers’, and ‘Two Against Nature’), and its kurtosis score suggests that these outlying scores are more extreme than we’d expect (and certainly more extreme than for most other publications).
All of this supports the idea that Pitchfork is generally a trusted source of music criticism, but that it has a habit of being unnecessarily contrarian to provoke attention.

This is the first blog in my new ‘Music By Numbers’ column, which will use data to tell stories about the modern music industry. How are changing genre tastes affecting festivals? What is the future of music journalism? Is making the ‘Difficult Third Album’ as hard as people think?
